title: How to Make Your Own Mosaic Bathroom Countertop

steps.headline: Remove the current bathroom countertop, if you choose to do so.
steps.description: You will need a crowbar to peel the countertop away from the bottom surface and wall. You can also glue your tile on top of your current countertop.

steps.headline: Choose the tiles you want to use for your bathroom countertop.
steps.description: Ceramic tiles are a good choice, and they are available at hardware and home improvement stores. Do not choose too many bright colors for your mosaic surface. A surface made mostly of shades of neutrals and 1 or 2 bright colors will match your décor without looking too busy. You may choose tiles in the same size or of varying sizes. Consider choosing a different colored tile for the perimeter.

steps.headline: Measure the dimensions of the bathroom countertop you would like to tile.
Lay your tiles out on a dry surface.
steps.description: Arrange the design that you would like to use, accounting for the dimensions of your bathroom sink. If you are working with large tiles you can place them in a thick plastic bag and hit them with a hammer to break them into smaller pieces. This will give you a more hap-hazard, uneven look than if you use small square tiles. Use a ceramic cutter to clip your tiles into specific shapes. For example, you may want to clip your square tiles diagonally to fit them around a curved wash basin.

steps.headline: Clean the surface of your countertop.
steps.description: Use a heavy duty cleanser. Allow it to dry.

steps.headline: Stir your ceramic tile adhesive.
steps.description: Tile adhesive and caulk are available at home improvement stores.

steps.headline: Apply the adhesive to your countertop surface with a trowel.
steps.description: Spread it evenly before placing your tile on the surface.

steps.headline: Place your tiles onto the adhesive 1 by 1, according to your design.
steps.description: Place them approximately 1/2 inch (1.3 cm) apart from the next tile, to create the mosaic look. Make sure not to press them too deep into the adhesive, as the top should remain clean, with room for grout on the sides.

steps.headline: Continue adding tiles to your mosaic until all of the pieces are placed on the countertop.
steps.description: Allow the tiles to dry for 24 hours, or as long as the adhesive directions indicate.

steps.headline: Mix your sanded grout according to package directions, or buy a pre-mixed grout.
Apply the sanded grout with a sponge squeegee.
steps.description: Do small areas of the countertop 1 at a time, so that you can be sure you have filled the spaces completely with grout. Move the squeegee diagonally across the surface before moving vertically or horizontally.

steps.headline: Mix a weak solution of white vinegar and warm water to clean your tiles while the grout is still wet.
steps.description: Dip a sponge into the solution and wring out the excess liquid.

steps.headline: Wipe your tiles until they appear clean.
Leave your grout to dry according to package instructions.
Apply 1 to 2 coats of water-resistant sealer to your bathroom countertop with a paint brush or sponge.
steps.description: This will help to avoid mold growth and make the counter easier to clean. Allow the sealer to dry well between coats.

text: Countertop Preparation Remove the current bathroom countertop, if you choose to do so. You will need a crowbar to peel the countertop away from the bottom surface and wall. You can also glue your tile on top of your current countertop. Choose the tiles you want to use for your bathroom countertop. Ceramic tiles are a good choice, and they are available at hardware and home improvement stores. Do not choose too many bright colors for your mosaic surface. A surface made mostly of shades of neutrals and 1 or 2 bright colors will match your décor without looking too busy. You may choose tiles in the same size or of varying sizes. Consider choosing a different colored tile for the perimeter. Measure the dimensions of the bathroom countertop you would like to tile.  Lay your tiles out on a dry surface. Arrange the design that you would like to use, accounting for the dimensions of your bathroom sink. If you are working with large tiles you can place them in a thick plastic bag and hit them with a hammer to break them into smaller pieces. This will give you a more hap-hazard, uneven look than if you use small square tiles. Use a ceramic cutter to clip your tiles into specific shapes. For example, you may want to clip your square tiles diagonally to fit them around a curved wash basin. Clean the surface of your countertop. Use a heavy duty cleanser. Allow it to dry. Mosaic Countertop Application Stir your ceramic tile adhesive. Tile adhesive and caulk are available at home improvement stores. Apply the adhesive to your countertop surface with a trowel. Spread it evenly before placing your tile on the surface. Place your tiles onto the adhesive 1 by 1, according to your design. Place them approximately 1/2 inch (1.3 cm) apart from the next tile, to create the mosaic look. Make sure not to press them too deep into the adhesive, as the top should remain clean, with room for grout on the sides. Continue adding tiles to your mosaic until all of the pieces are placed on the countertop. Allow the tiles to dry for 24 hours, or as long as the adhesive directions indicate. Mix your sanded grout according to package directions, or buy a pre-mixed grout.  Apply the sanded grout with a sponge squeegee. Do small areas of the countertop 1 at a time, so that you can be sure you have filled the spaces completely with grout. Move the squeegee diagonally across the surface before moving vertically or horizontally. Mix a weak solution of white vinegar and warm water to clean your tiles while the grout is still wet. Dip a sponge into the solution and wring out the excess liquid. Wipe your tiles until they appear clean.  Leave your grout to dry according to package instructions.  Apply 1 to 2 coats of water-resistant sealer to your bathroom countertop with a paint brush or sponge. This will help to avoid mold growth and make the counter easier to clean. Allow the sealer to dry well between coats.
